title: Energy and pd - X and Y move on isoline map

content.question:
The equipotential map shown in the figure represents a region of electric field where there are two identical, positively-charged particles, Particle <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and Particle <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> (not shown). Particle <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> is initially located at Point <math alttext="X sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, and Particle <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> is initially located at Point <math alttext="Y sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. The particles are released from rest at the same time and start moving. Later, external forces stop Particle <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> when it reaches Point <math alttext="X sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and Particle <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> when it reaches Point <math alttext="Y sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and again hold them in place.
The particles are far enough apart that they do not significantly interact with one another. Is the change in potential energy <math alttext="delta U sub X f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>U</mi><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math> of the Particle <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>-field system equal to the change in potential energy <math alttext="delta U sub Y f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>U</mi><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></math> of the Particle <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>-field system? What evidence or reasoning supports the claim?

choices.label: Yes, <math alttext="delta U sub X f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>U</mi><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta U sub Y f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>U</mi><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></math> are equal. Both particles reach their final positions at the same time.

Yes, <math alttext="delta U sub X f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>U</mi><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta U sub Y f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>U</mi><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></math> are equal. Both particles move through the same change in electric potential.

No, <math alttext="delta U sub X f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>U</mi><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta U sub Y f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>U</mi><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></math> are not equal. The distance traveled by Particle <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> is longer than that traveled by Particle <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>.

No, <math alttext="delta U sub X f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>U</mi><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta U sub Y f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>U</mi><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></math> are not equal. The acceleration of Particle <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> is greater in magnitude than that of Particle <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>.

content.answer: Yes, <math alttext="delta U sub X f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>U</mi><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="delta U sub Y f, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>U</mi><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></math> are equal. Both particles move through the same change in electric potential.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
